The late Dr. Husband of Duufermline called on him when he was preparing to set out for Gifford, and was beginning to ask him some questions as to the place grace held in the Divine economy. ‘Come away wi’ me, and I’ll expound that, but when I’m speaking, look you after my feet.' They got upon a rough bit of common, and the eager and full-minded old man was in the midst of his unfold- ing the Divine scheme, aud his student was drinking in his words, and forgetting his part of the bargain. His master stumbled and fell, and getting up, some· what sharply said, ‘James, the grace o' God can do much, but it canna gi'e a man common sense 3' which is as good theology as sense.
